attributes.Title: ST-Filipino I
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Five Coll Ctr: World Languages
197FA
UMass Amherst
Filipino I is the first part of a four-part elementary course sequence in Filipino.  The course is offered through the Five College Supervised Independent Language Program.  The independent study format includes small group conversation sessions and an evaluation by an outside evaluator.  Students studying Filipino develop speaking and listening skills needed for study abroad in the Philippines and to support course work in Southeast Asian Studies
Students must apply to add this course at www.fivecolleges.edu/fclang.
For info email: fclang@fivecolleges.edu or call 413-542-5264.
Permission is required for interchange registration during all registration periods.

attributes.Title: ST-Persian VI
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Five Coll Ctr: World Languages
197GE
UMass Amherst
Persian VI is an intermediate-level course for students who have completed Persian I-V or the equivalent. The course teaches Iranian Persian (Farsi). It is also useful for students who want to learn Dari (Persian as spoken in Afghanistan) or Tajik (Persian as spoken in Tajikistan). The course is offered through the Five College Mentored Language Program. The course format includes small group conversation sessions and individual tutorials. Students studying Persian develop speaking, listening, reading, writing, and cultural etiquette skills needed for study abroad and to support course work in Middle Eastern and Central Asian Studies.
Students must apply to add this course at www.fivecolleges.edu/fclang.
For info email: fclang@fivecolleges.edu or call 413-542-5264.

attributes.Title: Ideas That Change the World
attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Honors College
201
UMass Amherst
In this seminar, students will examine texts and works of art that have profoundly shaped the world we live in. The course is divided into four units: Models of Inquiry; the Impact of Science and Technology; Social Philosophy and Civic Engagement; and Art in the World. The course is supplemented with several plenary lectures by distinguished honors faculty speakers.
This course is open to Commonwealth Honors College students only.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
16389

Varies from 1 to 18 credits
Permission is required for interchange registration during all registration periods.

attributes.Title: ST-Trad Herbal Med Sys II
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Stockbridge Sch of Agriculture
297F
UMass Amherst
An examination of indigenous medicinal systems from around the world to understand the choices of herbal medicines used by traditional healers and the similarities and differences in the approach of treatments. Students will be exposed to a wise range of cultures including Ayurvedic, Chinese, African, Middle Eastern, European, Central Asian, Native American, and Amazonian. No prerequisites. PLSOILION 297C and D can be taken in any sequence
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
65133

attributes.Title: ST- Korean Language: Lit
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Asian Studies
497C
UMass Amherst
In this course, students will learn advanced level Korean through Korean literature. Students will achieve deeper understanding of Korean culture and society through a lens of literature. Students will read the various genres of literature texts, write reflection journals, and discuss about them in class. Assignments will include creative writing and literary translation. Academic reading and writing skills will be the forefront learning goal; however, formal speaking and listening will be emphasized as well. By the end of the course, students will be able to describe, narrate, compare, and report a paragraph level discourse in a coherent manner. Students will also be able to talk about abstract concepts.
ASIAN-ST 397C
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: ST-Beginning Korean II
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Asian Studies
197C
UMass Amherst
This course is the second part of the Beginning Korean sequence, which is designed to teach the fundamental skills to read, write, listen and speak in elementary level Korean.  Prior to taking this course, students are expected to read Hangul and to be able to talk about simple daily activities and carry a limited conversation with memorized phrases.  Compared to the first semester, more advanced vocabulary and grammar patterns will be introduced, and the students will learn how to integrate them into developed forms of application.  By the end of the course, students will be able to handle a variety of uncomplicated communicative tasks successfully and will be able to ask a few formulaic questions.  In addition to the textbook study in the classroom, audio-visual materials and activities will be used in class.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
61597

attributes.Title: ST-Current Issues in Korea
attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Asian Studies
497E
UMass Amherst
This is an advanced Korean language class designed to improve students Korean proficiency through studying news articles. In this course, students will read current news articles, discuss them and analyze them in relation to Korea?s social, cultural and historical context. Some of the activities include reading and summarizing news articles, news report presentations, translation of the news articles, and writing an opinion journal. By the end of the course, students will be able to describe, report, narrate, and compare in a paragraph level discourse in a coherent manner. Students will also able to support their opinions and talk about abstract concepts. Students will also gain a deeper understanding of the current Korean society.
Open to students who have taken three years of Korean or equivalent to advanced Korean.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
19527

attributes.Title: ST-Brg As&Asn Am Gen
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Asian Studies
397B
UMass Amherst
Talks by local and visiting faculty, as well as film screenings and performances, designed to introduce students to the multi-layered connections between Asia and Asian America.  Areas that will be considered include: popular culture, youth subcultures, labor, issues of gender and sexuality, and migration and immigrant communities.  Discussions emphasize how issues play out at local, national and transnational levels.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
31606

For info email: fclang@fivecolleges.edu or call 413-542-5264.
Permission is required for interchange registration during all registration periods.
67258

attributes.Title: ST-Mongolian III
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Five Coll Ctr: World Languages
197FC
UMass Amherst
Mongolian III is the third part of a four-part elementary course sequence in Mongolian. The course is offered through the Five College Supervised Independent Language Program. The independent study format includes small group conversation sessions and an evaluation by an outside evaluator. Students studying Mongolian develop speaking and listening skills needed for study abroad in Mongolia and to support course work in Asian Studies.
Students must apply to add this course at www.fivecolleges.edu/fclang.

67245

attributes.Title: ST-Persian VII
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Five Coll Ctr: World Languages
197GF
UMass Amherst
Persian VII is an intermediate-level course for students who have completed Persian I-VI or the equivalent. The course teaches Iranian Persian (Farsi). It is also useful for students who want to learn Dari (Persian as spoken in Afghanistan) or Tajik (Persian as spoken in Tajikistan). The course is offered through the Five College Mentored Language Program. The course format includes small group conversation sessions and individual tutorials. Students studying Persian develop speaking, listening, reading, writing, and cultural etiquette skills needed for study abroad and to support course work in Middle Eastern and Central Asian Studies.
Students must apply to add this course at www.fivecolleges.edu/fclang.
For info email: fclang@fivecolleges.edu or call 413-542-5264.
Permission is required for interchange registration during all registration periods.
67229

attributes.Title: ST-Beginning Korean I
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Asian Studies
197B
UMass Amherst
This is an introductory Korean course, which is designed to help students acquire fundamental skills to read, write, listen and speak in elementary level Korean. Students will learn Korean writing system, Hangul, simple sentence patterns, and basic everyday conversations. By the end of the class, students will be able to carry a short conversation about people's backgrounds, likes and dislikes, attributes, as well as location, numbers and counters.  Students will also be able to talk about present, past and future events in straightforward social situations.  In addition to the classroom instruction, students will meet with a TA to practice speaking.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
